RediscoveryExport.Description: 3000 books; 35000 periodicals; 23000 45 rpm recordings; 13000 10 inch 78 rpm recordings; 3000 12 inch 33 1/3 rpm recordings; 2500 10 inch 33 1/3 rpm recordings; 1500 12 inch 78 rpm recordings; 500 10 inch 78 rpm recordings (sets); 200 VHS video tapes; 250 CD's; 300 audio cassette tapes; 500 large and small reel-to-reel tape recordings; sets of caller's notes, photographs, dancer's badges, club banners, caller's equipment (record players, tape players, video tape players, film projectors), newspaper clippings, callers' correspondence, musical instruments (estimates based on Lloyd Shaw archivist's description). Seperate special collections included: 1. The Collection of Jimmy Clossin (West Texas Caller); 2. The Mary D. Walsh Collection (Ft. Worth, TX); 3. The Lloyd Shaw Collection of dance recordings and personal correspondence (from La Semilla, Colorado Springs, CO); 4. The Bob and Al Brundage Collection; 5. The Rose Bowl Parade Square Dance Collection; 6. Personal recorded and transcribed interviews with square and round dance teachers from the United States. (Most interviews conducted by Bob Brundage.); 7. Collection of early English and American printed sources for social dance (primarily photocopied material). (All description provided by Lloyd Shaw Archivist's.)

RediscoveryExport.Archival_Appraisal: These records were an accrual to the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver Records, B182.
RediscoveryExport.Description: The Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver case files consist of personal files arranged in alphabetical order. Materials included are case forms, accounts of financial assistance, notes from caseworkers, correspondence, court minutes, and IQ tests. Records are from 1921-1969 in 57 legal document boxes, containing over 3,000 social work cases, the majority of which were closed between 1948 and 1965. The early cases deal with new immigrants to Denver, while the later ones deal with family problems.
RediscoveryExport.Note_s_: The date of the Deaccession Form is July 11, 2002.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: The Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver created the records which were sent to the American Jewish Historical Society on May 1, 1975. The American Jewish Historical Society deacessioned the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver, Records, 1921-1969, I-65, to the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Society on July 1, 2002.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance_Condition: The Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver created the records which were sent to the American Jewish Historical Society on May 1, 1975. The American Jewish Historical Society deacessioned the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver, Records, 1921-1969, I-65, to the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Society on July 1, 2002.

RediscoveryExport.Note_s_: This accession includes records from two different organizations: the National Asthma Center and the National Jewish Hospital: 24 boxes of the National Asthma Center Records, B089, and the over 200 boxes of the National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives' Records, B005. The accession contains the organizational records of National Jewish Hospital, including minutes, legal and financial records, correspondence, publications, objects, photographs, and scrapbooks. In 1989, a long-term agreement was settled on by the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine and the Center for Judaic Studies. On September 22, 2005, the President/CEO of National Jewish Medical and Research Center executed a Deed of Gift Agreement donating the archival records of the National Asthma Center and the National Jewish Hospital to the Ira M. Beck Memorial Archives. The Deed of Gift applies to prior and future gifts from the National Jewish Hospital. There is a yearly $500 maintenance fee.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: The National Asthma Center merged into the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine in 1978. In 2005 the National Jewish Medical and Research Center donated the archival records produced by the National Asthma Center and the National Jewish Hospital to the Ira M. Beck Memorial Archives.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance_Condition: The National Asthma Center merged into the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine in 1978. In 2005 the National Jewish Medical and Research Center donated the archival records produced by the National Asthma Center and the National Jewish Hospital to the Ira M. Beck Memorial Archives.
RediscoveryExport.Source: National Jewish Medical and Research Center (U.S.)

RediscoveryExport.Archival_Appraisal: At the request of the donor, four separate collections were created from the materials in this accession. They are Irene Miller Stein Family Objects, Artwork, and Papers (B173), Norma Peterman Clothing, Correspondence, and Other Material (B211), Pencol Drug Store Objects and Papers, (B217), and Sophie Peterman Wedding Dress (B249).
RediscoveryExport.Description: This accession contains material items that belonged to the family of Irene (nee Miller) Stein, including Wedding Dress of Sophie Peterman, 1915 and miscellaneous papers, documents, and receipts relating to Robert Lazar Miller. Norma Peterman items: Condolence cards, term paper, autobiography and baby clothing items of Norma Peterman. 2 Ivory Fans, Leather Baby Shoes, 1 silk slip, 1 cotton slip, 1 silk dress. Irene Stein Family Collection: 4 Scrapbooks, 1960s and 1970s. Photograph and Feather "Egg Brush" of Bessie Miller, ca. 1880s. (Bessie Miller was the grandmother of Irene Stein.) Purse of Irene Stein, black velvet, ca. 1915. Wallets and change purses belonging to Robert Lazar Miller, father of Irene, ca. 1910. Watercolor sketch of stained glass window at BMH donated by Robert Lazar Miller. Memorial Fund Register Book and Shiners Hat of Azreil Stein. Wedding Certificate of Irene and Azreil Stein, 1921. 50 year Masonic Pin, 1921, cards and Masonic Certificate, 1920 belonging to Azreil Stein.
RediscoveryExport.Note_s_: The Past Perfect record and the accession card have the incorrect spelling of Azriel.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: The materials donated belonged to Irene Stein, her grandmother Bessie and her father Robert Lazar Miller, her husband Azriel and her son Stanley Stein, her sister Sophie Peterman, and her niece Norma Peterman and were donated by Irene Stein to the Beck Archives in 1990.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance_Condition: The materials donated belonged to Irene Stein, her grandmother Bessie and her father Robert Lazar Miller, her husband Azriel and her son Stanley Stein, her sister Sophie Peterman, and her niece Norma Peterman and were donated by Irene Stein to the Beck Archives in 1990.

RediscoveryExport.Description: Prayer book, 1909, of Esther Fishman Striker (mother-in-law). Maternal Grandparents from Eastern Europe: Tefillin, Tallis, 1 Book of Psalms.
RediscoveryExport.Note_s_: One of the objects in this collection is known as a tallit according to Sephardic pronunciation or a tallis according to Ashkenazic pronunciation, so in documentation it is alternately referred to as tallit or tallis. The tefillin and tallit accessions also included accompanying bags.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: The Rosh Hashanah machzor (prayer book) was given to Betty Striker's mother-in-law, Esther Fishman Striker, on her wedding day in 1909. Esther was married to Alex Striker. The tefillin, tallit, and book of Psalms belonged to Betty's maternal grandparents, the Jacobsons, who were from Eastern Europe.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance_Condition: The Rosh Hashanah machzor (prayer book) was given to Betty Striker's mother-in-law, Esther Fishman Striker, on her wedding day in 1909. Esther was married to Alex Striker. The tefillin, tallit, and book of Psalms belonged to Betty's maternal grandparents, the Jacobsons, who were from Eastern Europe.

RediscoveryExport.Description: The collection includes newspaper and magazine articles, photographs relating to the history of the Kobey/Rachofsky/Shwayder family, family tree charts and other printed material, an original photograph of the Sheffel sisters, and a compact disc with photographs and printed materials supplied by Ted and Jessie Shwayder Harsham.
RediscoveryExport.Note_s_: Some copies of the original documents and articles are included in the digital images and some are not. The digital images include photographs, copies of the original documents, and additional documents. Two images of the original photograph of the Sheffel sisters are also included on the compact disc.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: These are documents and newspaper and magazine articles relating to the history of the Kobey/Rachofsky/Shwayder families given to the Beck Archives at the time of the interview with Dokes Berry that was conducted on July 22, 2002. Ted E. Harsham created digital images in 2001 and 2002 from materials at Dokes Berry's home and gave the images on a compact disc to the archives in 2005. The original photo of the Sheffel sisters, that includes Dokes Kobey's mother, was given to the archives on September 26, 2005.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance_Condition: These are documents and newspaper and magazine articles relating to the history of the Kobey/Rachofsky/Shwayder families given to the Beck Archives at the time of the interview with Dokes Berry that was conducted on July 22, 2002. Newspapers and magazines concerning Mormonism and the Methodist response to the Mormon Church. Also included are letters written to Spencer in his capacity as editor of the Central Christian Advocate.
Half of the collection is comprised of typescript pages and handwritten notes from a manuscript titled: Holiness and Mormonism. The author of the manuscript is unknown. The manuscript describes the origins of Mormonism and, through lengthy discussion, refutes the legitimacy of the Mormon Church.

The School of Architecture and Planning Records contain brochures, bulletins, correspondence, reports, course descriptions, lists of applicants and degree candidates, minutes and memos from the Architectural Advisory Committee, and material on the formation and closing of the School. The materials in file folders 1-10 have been microfilmed, a copy of which is available both in the University of Denver Archives and in the Carl Feiss Collection at Cornell University. A calendar listing individual items in folders 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 9 is available in the University of Denver Archives office.

Author - manuscript for Harvey.
RediscoveryExport.Note_s_: The letter from Mary Chase indicates that she was going to donate the three manuscripts to DU: Harvey (originally titled The Pooka), Mrs. McThing and Bernadine. She was also going to bequeath the Pulitzer Prize Certificate for Harvey. An acknowledgement was not sent to her until 1964, but it referenced the same three plays. What we have in the collection is two copies of Harvey, a copy of The Wicked Pigeon Ladies in the Garden, and two copies of Loretta Mason Potts. We do not have Mrs. McThing or Bernadine. There is no indication in the files as to what happened. (mak 2/4/2008)
